{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3484565,"name":"Ibrahim","username":"Ibracream","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/4af34b/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-16T15:44:29.933Z","cooked":"

Hi, my team is a second-year team based in the Philippines. We decided to use a mechanism similar to this year’s cranberry alarm bot (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jw1JUITSX7w) where coral is fed down a ramp and through the back of a coral mech. The problem is we were late for ordering an elevator and the WCP Greyt elevator is the only option. The Greyt elevator has a pulley mechanism that runs in the middle of the elevator, which would block the coral route that we want to have. As far as i can tell, the points where the pulley system are connected is at the gearbox at the bottom, which can be moved, then at the top. It looks a bit narrow at the top but we can probably widen the elevator to allow it to shift. The last bit that looks like it is in the way is this chain attachment bracket. Can we cut that bracket down a bit to allow it to be moved?

If we can move it like that, will the fact that it would be uncentered cause problems with force distribution or something that will slow down or damage the elevator?

If we cant move it like that, what else can we do to clear that path?

Thanks.

image617×630 86.7 KB

The bearing blocks can probably handle the imbalanced force distribution if you move it, but it is hard to say for sure. Cutting the chain attachment plates would increase strain on the remaining screws and it could break. I think it could work though. I could also be entirely wrong.

You could also just make the carriage bigger. This would make it so you would not have to Cut the chain bracket. Here is a link to a onshape doc with a configurable elevator, so you can find out the exact lengths you would need.
Onshape
